titleStmt.title: Letter from Florence Henniker to Thomas Hardy — H.3174

physDesc.p: Folded card of cream stock with a printed black border and printed crest “The Little Orchard, Shoreham, Kent.” in black at the head of the first page. Written in a slightly sloping grey pencil/ink hand on all four sides, with extensive cross-writing in margins and between lines.

profileDesc.abstract: Florence Henniker writes from Shoreham to congratulate Thomas Hardy on his Cambridge fellowship, comment on dramatic and poetic adaptations of his work, discuss contemporary poetry readings, and share news of mutual acquaintances.

handDesc.handNote: Single rapid cursive hand in grey pencil or pale ink, with cross-writing.

profileDesc.note: Florence Ellen Hungerford Henniker (1855–1923), novelist and short story writer, was a close friend and sometimes collaborator of Thomas Hardy. This letter, written from her home “The Little Orchard” at Shoreham, Kent, comments on stage and poetic responses to Hardy’s work and reflects their long literary friendship.

notesStmt.note: Card stock, cream, with printed black rule around the recto of the first page. Writing medium appears to be soft pencil or very pale ink. Cross-writing runs at right angles across margins and between lines.
Printed oval device at head of first page reads: “The Little Orchard. Shoreham. Kent.”

body.p: How nice of you to write to me from Cambridge! and thank you too for telling me that you are pleased to have this link with Arthur in belonging to his old college. Magdalene must be proud to have you as a Fellow. I hope it may be cheering to you, & a real interest to go there from time to time.
body.seg: many more stories in your new book; some day I must talk to you about them.
body.p: I see in to-day’s "D[aily] Mail" an account of the "Woodlanders" & a picture of Marty South. It will be interesting to hear how far you — I, for perhaps you saw the rehearsals, at any rate — & Miss Drysdale, think she came at near to your conception of the character? It is rather wonderful if an untrained actress succeeded in satisfying people who care for the book. I daresay Miss D. will kindly write & tell me about it.
body.seg: I thought the "Tryst at the ancient earthwork" extremely good — such a difficult thing to do! "The Wedding Supper", "The Grave by the Hand-post", & "A Mere Interlude" are very characteristic of you — including that dramatic situation of the honeymoon in the letter — the Committee’s "Moon of Three Terrors" is very original & I so admire that last paragraph "that outline against the stars of the morning" — so graphic! "Alveira Dian" interested me, but in some ways it is unlike you, I think?
body.p: I am going to send you a very small vol. of really charming poems by Miss Wedmore. I think "England" & "The Grand Duke’s Funeral" especially good. I hope she will have the praise she deserves from some of the critics. Sir F. Wedmore gave a great deal of encouragement to people who care for true poetry.
I hope you are feeling better, & that vein in your leg does not now give trouble?

This place seems to suit me, & I am doing a good deal in the garden & hope to encourage many birds to make it their home. We had a very interesting poetry reading the other evening in Sevenoaks. He read your "Burgh" & "The Rash Bride" (the latter particularly well). I thought also a beautiful little poem "Twilight", by Masefield, which I am sure wd. appeal to you, & a lovely little lyric "Jenny’s Daughter", by Mona O’Neill — intensely pathetic in its simplicity. Do you know it? I wonder if you are writing more verse now? I have read a great deal with admiration.
